instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
Hello Everybody

I m working on liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B SMC area around, cleaned by ultrasonic now fan spin and turn off loop.

Stable voltages :
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.5V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V

But <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> up 3v and down 0

Already replaced SMC and looked bad parts nothing changed, any idea for next step?

Thanks.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is created by the PCH not the SMC. what does <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> look like?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1800</CHIP> will look like a PCH.

<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> will be the first suspect here, replace.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 18463"]<CHIP>U1800</CHIP> will look like a PCH.[/QUOTE]
:rolleyes:

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: thanks [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] and [USER="803"]SoloHarty[/USER]  after replace <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and y2805 machine start to work :)

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: For next time Y2805 almost never has to be replaced, if ever! But good to know it is solved.
